Even if they still had 8500 tons of bars, it would only provide $5 trillion at best, which will soon be merely the annual deficit. The devaluation of the dollar means the debt gets paid back via much smaller dollars. It is exactly the equivalent of a soft default, paying back 20% of the original value owed. This is what the "show off" to visiting politicians who are too stupid to know better. The only reason why they would still have their coin bars is because if they tried to steal and sell them, any refiner on earth would immediate recognize these came from Fort Knox, so unlike regular fine gold, they couldn't be sold without publicly exposing the theft. The USA has probably been discreetly buying gold ever since they suddenly stopped talking about doing an audit. As Luke Gromen says: >All Roads Lead to Gold.

>>61856214 Yes — the statement is essentially real, and it comes from an actual European Union initiative, but it’s important to understand it correctly. Real context: The European Commission, under the leadership of Ursula von der Leyen, is preparing the Savings and Investments Union (SIU). Its goal is to better connect citizens’ savings with investments within the EU. This is part of a broader effort to strengthen Europe’s capital markets and competitiveness by improving how savings flow into productive investments. The statement shown in the image (“We’ll turn private savings into much needed investment.”) was posted as a tweet and it does exist. It circulated widely online and sparked public debate. Important clarification: This statement does not mean that the EU will seize people’s savings or take money from private bank accounts against their will. The initiative aims to create better conditions and incentives so that citizens who choose to do so can invest their savings more easily through European capital markets. There is no automatic or forced transfer of personal savings. So, to answer your question: Yes — the quote is based on a real tweet and a real EU policy initiative. It was not fabricated, but it has often been shared without proper context, which can lead to misleading interpretations. If you want, I can also explain what the Savings and Investments Union would mean in practice and what concrete measures are being discussed.

item.title: Thread 61856272 — 15 replies
item.description:
Thread 61856272

Replies: 15

OP:
Anons, i want to divest from the US. I see a lot of companies and people doing it. I don't want to be the last one left. I don't want to invest in crypto since a lot of countries are starting to pass regulations for it. I don't want to invest in China. Where should i put my money in? Any ideas?

61856281:
>>61856272 invest in europe.

61856290:
Invest in Japanese industry. Particularly companies that produce equipment for the nuclear energy sector

61856297:
>>61856281 >invest in europe That's very broad. Got any specific leads? People have been trying to tell me to invest in defence stocks but everyone seems to be trying to bid for those right now and i am not a big enough player.

61856302:
>>61856290 Good advise. Japan is going to try and make their own nukes so they will invest more into that sector. So i guess i'll do a split between Europe and Japan. Now i just need to find the right stocks.

61856305:
>>61856272 >https://www.justetf.com/en/etf-profile.html?isin=IE0006WW1TQ4 Take this as base and add some individual EM countries that you want. Mexico, South East Asia, Turkey, Argentina...your choice

61856312:
>>61856297 defence isn't a bad bet. if you're looking for single companies you should look for defence adjacent industrial businesses that are now adapting their production to defence, of which there are plenty. there is also a european defence ETF by wisdromtree, but you're buying mostly rheinmetall and saab with that one. honestly i think that you will already outperform the S&P500 with an MSCI Europe ETF for the next couple of years, especially if the USD falls further against the EUR, so i would just go with that.

61856315:
>>61856290 What is it about Japan that makes white people turn into annoying third world brownoids?

61856319:
>>61856272 >I don't want to invest in China you doing it everyday

61856325:
>>61856312 >MSCI Europe ETF I would buy msci eafe etf since it gives you japan exposure too

61856335:
>>61856302 Itochu, Hitachi and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries are the best options

61856338:
>>61856315 It's the top tier pussy

61856339:
>>61856272 you also need to factor in exchange rates, you cannot really predict what markets are going to do the best, but what you can do is invest in the markets of countries with the weakest currencies compared to their history. That way you get to invest in markets at a discount and stack the numbers in your favor. Some good options: Japan, Australia, Mexico, Canada

61856350:
Thanks for all the good advice /biz/bros.

61856370:
>>61856297 EXUS is a good start. EU Defense and finance sector broke records last year, you would be chasing those profits now. Something to keep eye on is infra imo.

61856537:
